posts.title: Codeforces Round #629 (Div. 3)
posts.text: A. Divisibility ProblemYou are given two positive integers a and b. In one move you can increase aa by 1 (replace a with a+1). Your task is to find the minimum number of moves you need to do in order to make a divisible by b. It is possible, that you have to make 0 moves, as a is already divisible by b. You have to answer t independent test cases. InputThe first line of the input contains one integer t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 104) â€” the number of test cases. Then t test cases follow. The only line of the test case contains two integers a and b (1 â‰¤ a, b â‰¤ 109). OutputFor each test case print the answer â€” the minimum number of moves you need to do in order to make a divisible by b. Exampleinput 5 10 4 13 9 100 13 123 456 92 46 output 2 5 4 333 0 Problem solvingé¢˜æ„å°±æ˜¯ç»™ä½ ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•´æ•°a,bã€‚aæ¯æ¬¡å¯ä»¥+1å˜æˆa+1,é—®aéœ€è¦åŠ å¤šå°‘æ¬¡æ‰å¯ä»¥å˜æˆbçš„å€æ•°ã€‚ è¿™é“é¢˜åªéœ€è¦ç”¨b-a%bå°±è¡Œäº†ã€‚æ³¨æ„aå¯èƒ½æœ¬èº«å°±æ˜¯bçš„å€æ•°ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æœ€åéœ€è¦å†å¯¹bå–æ¨¡ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; typedef long long ll; inline void solve() { ll a,b; cin>>a>>b; cout<<(b - a % b) % b<<endl; } int main() { int T;cin>>T; while(T--) solve(); return 0; } B. K-th Beautiful StringFor the given integer n (n > 2) letâ€™s write down all the strings of length n which contain nâˆ’2 letters â€˜aâ€™ and two letters â€˜bâ€™ in lexicographical (alphabetical) order. Recall that the string s of length n is lexicographically less than string t of length n, if there exists such i (1 â‰¤ i â‰¤n), that s i < t i , and for any j (1 â‰¤ j < i) s i = t i. The lexicographic comparison of strings is implemented by the operator < in modern programming languages. For example, if n=5 the strings are (the order does matter): aaabb aabab aabba abaab ababa abbaa baaab baaba babaa bbaaa It is easy to show that such a list of strings will contain exactly $\frac{nâ‹…(nâˆ’1)}{2}$ strings. You are given n (n > 2) and kk (1â‰¤ k â‰¤ $\frac{nÂ·(n-1)}{2}$). Print the k-th string from the list. InputThe input contains one or more test cases. The first line contains one integer t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 104) â€” the number of test cases in the test. Then t test cases follow. Each test case is written on the the separate line containing two integers n and k (3 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 105,1 â‰¤ k â‰¤ min(2â‹…109, $\frac{nâ‹…(nâˆ’1)}{2}$). The sum of values n over all test cases in the test doesnâ€™t exceed 105. OutputFor each test case print the k-th string from the list of all described above strings of length n. Strings in the list are sorted lexicographically (alphabetically). Exampleinput 7 5 1 5 2 5 8 5 10 3 1 3 2 20 100 output aaabb aabab baaba bbaaa abb bab aaaaabaaaaabaaaaaaaa Problem solvingé¢˜æ„æ˜¯è¯´ç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ªnå’Œk, æ±‚ç”¨n-2ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ â€˜aâ€™ å’Œ2ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ â€˜bâ€™ è¿›è¡Œå…¨æ’åˆ—åå­—å…¸åºç¬¬kå¤§çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ã€‚ å› ä¸º â€˜aâ€™ çš„å­—å…¸åºæ¯” â€˜bâ€™ å°ï¼Œå†æ ¹æ®æ ·ä¾‹å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å…ˆæ‰¾åˆ°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª â€˜bâ€™çš„ä½ç½®ï¼Œå› ä¸ºç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª â€˜bâ€™ çš„ä½ç½®æ˜¯æœ‰è§„å¾‹çš„ï¼Œä»å€’æ•°ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå¼€å§‹ï¼Œä¾æ¬¡å¾€å·¦åˆ†åˆ«æœ‰1,2,3,4,5,6ï¼Œâ€¦ï¼Œi ä¸ªã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç”¨kä¾æ¬¡å‡æ‰è¿™äº›æ•°ï¼Œå½“kå°äºç­‰äº i æ—¶ï¼Œå°±æ‰¾åˆ°äº†ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª â€˜bâ€™ çš„ä½ç½®p1ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥p1 = n - i; ç„¶åç¬¬äºŒä¸ª â€˜bâ€™ å°±æœ‰ n - i - 1ä¸ªä½ç½®å¯ä»¥æ”¾ã€‚æ”¾çš„è¶Šé åå­—å…¸åºè¶Šå°ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; inline void solve() { int n,k; cin>>n>>k; int i; for(i=1;;i++) { if(k<=i) break; k-=i; } int p1,p2; p1 = n-i; p2 = n-k+1; for(i=1; i<=n; i++) if(i==p1 ||i==p2) cout<<"b"; else cout<<"a"; cout<<endl; } int main() { int T; cin>>T; while(T--) solve(); return 0; } C. Ternary XORA number is ternary if it contains only digits 00, 11 and 22. For example, the following numbers are ternary: 1022, 11, 21, 2002. You are given a long ternary number x. The first (leftmost) digit of x is guaranteed to be 2, the other digits of xx can be 0, 1 or 2. Letâ€™s define the ternary XOR operation âŠ™ of two ternary numbers aa and bb (both of length n) as a number c=aâŠ™b of length n, where ci=(ai+bi)%3 (where % is modulo operation). In other words, add the corresponding digits and take the remainders of the sums when divided by 3. For example, 10222âŠ™11021=21210. Your task is to find such ternary numbers aa and b both of length n and both without leading zeros that aâŠ™b=x and max(a,b) is the minimum possible. You have to answer t independent test cases. InputThe first line of the input contains one integer t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 104) â€” the number of test cases. Then t test cases follow. The first line of the test case contains one integer n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 5â‹…104) â€” the length of x. The second line of the test case contains ternary number x consisting of n digits 0,1 or 2. It is guaranteed that the first digit of x is 2. It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 5â‹…104 (âˆ‘n â‰¤ 5â‹…104). OutputFor each test case, print the answer â€” two ternary integers aa and bb both of length n and both without leading zeros such that aâŠ™b = x and max(a,b) is the minimum possible. If there are several answers, you can print any. Exampleinput 4 5 22222 5 21211 1 2 9 220222021 output 11111 11111 11000 10211 1 1 110111011 110111010 Problem solvingé¢˜æ„ä¸­å®šä¹‰äº†ä¸€ä¸ªä¸‰è¿›åˆ¶çš„å¼‚æˆ–è§„åˆ™(å¯¹åº”ä½ä¸Šçš„æ•°ç›¸åŠ ä½™3)ï¼Œç„¶åç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°xï¼Œè®©ä½ è¾“å‡ºä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°a,bï¼Œè¦ä¿è¯è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°çš„å¼‚æˆ–å’Œç­‰äºxï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¿™ä¿©ä¸ªæ•°çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼æœ€å°ã€‚å³ ï¼ša XOR b = x , max(a,b)å°½å¯èƒ½å°ã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¦å•ç‹¬åˆ†ææ¯ä¸€ä½ä¸Šçš„æ•°å³å¯ã€‚æ ¹æ®ä¸Šé¢çš„å¼‚æˆ–è§„åˆ™ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å¾—å‡ºï¼š 2 = 1 xor 1 æˆ– 0 xor 2 æˆ– 2 xor 0 (å› ä¸ºè¦ä¿è¯å°½å¯èƒ½å°ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥a+bä¸åº”å¤§äº3) 1 = 0 xor 1 æˆ– 1 xor 0 0 = 0 xor 0 æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¤a>bã€‚ä»å·¦åˆ°å³ä¾æ¬¡åˆ¤æ–­xçš„æ¯ä¸€ä½ï¼Œ å¦‚æœè¿˜æ²¡åˆ†å‡ºå¤§å°ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä¿è¯a,bå°½é‡ç›¸åŒï¼Œå³å½“x[i] = 2æ—¶ï¼Œa[i]=b[i]=1ï¼›å½“x[i] = 0æ—¶ï¼Œa[i]=b[i]=0ã€‚å½“x[i]=1æ—¶ï¼Œa[i]=1ï¼Œb[i]=0ï¼Œè¿™æ—¶æ— è®ºåé¢æ€ä¹ˆå–å€¼aå·²ç»å¤§äºbäº†; å¦‚æœå·²ç»åˆ†å‡ºäº†å¤§å°ï¼šåªéœ€è¦å°†aåé¢çš„å…¨éƒ½è¡¥0ï¼Œbåé¢ç…§æŠ„xå°±è¡Œäº†ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±ä¿è¯äº†å¤§å€¼aå°½å¯èƒ½å°ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; inline void solve() { int n; string s; cin>>n>>s; string a = "1",b = "1"; int flag = 1; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) { if(flag) { if(s[i] == '2') a += "1",b += "1"; if(s[i] == '0') a += "0",b += "0"; if(s[i] == '1') a += "1",b += "0",flag = 0; } else { a += "0"; b += s[i]; } } cout<<a<<endl<<b<<endl; } int main() { std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false); cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0); int T; cin>>T; while(T--) solve(); return 0; }

posts.title: Educational Codeforces Round 84 (Rated for Div. 2) Cã€E
posts.text: C. Game with ChipsPetya has a rectangular Board of size nÃ—m. Initially, k chips are placed on the board, i-th chip is located in the cell at the intersection of sxi-th row and syi-th column. In one action, Petya can move all the chips to the left, right, down or up by 11 cell. If the chip was in the (x, y) cell, then after the operation: left, its coordinates will be (x, y âˆ’ 1); right, its coordinates will be (x, y + 1); down, its coordinates will be (x + 1, y); up, its coordinates will be (x âˆ’ 1, y). If the chip is located by the wall of the board, and the action chosen by Petya moves it towards the wall, then the chip remains in its current position. Note that several chips can be located in the same cell. For each chip, Petya chose the position which it should visit. Note that itâ€™s not necessary for a chip to end up in this position. Since Petya does not have a lot of free time, he is ready to do no more than 2nm actions. You have to find out what actions Petya should do so that each chip visits the position that Petya selected for it at least once. Or determine that it is not possible to do this in 2nm actions. InputThe first line contains three integers n, m, k (1 â‰¤ n, m, k â‰¤ 200) â€” the number of rows and columns of the board and the number of chips, respectively. The next k lines contains two integers each sxi, syi (1 â‰¤ sxi â‰¤ n,1 â‰¤ syi â‰¤ m) â€” the starting position of the i-th chip. The next kk lines contains two integers each fxi, fyi (1 â‰¤ fxi â‰¤ n, 1 â‰¤ fyi â‰¤ m) â€” the position that the i-chip should visit at least once. OutputIn the first line print the number of operations so that each chip visits the position that Petya selected for it at least once. In the second line output the sequence of operations. To indicate operations left, right, down, and up, use the characters L,R,D,U respectively. If the required sequence does not exist, print -1 in the single line. Examplesinput 3 3 2 1 2 2 1 3 3 3 2 output 3 DRD input 5 4 3 3 4 3 1 3 3 5 3 1 3 1 4 output 9 DDLUUUURR Problem solvingé¢˜æ„å°±æ˜¯åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ª n*m çš„çŸ©é˜µä¸­ç»™ä½  k ä¸ªç‚¹çš„èµ·å§‹ä½ç½®å’Œç»ˆæ­¢ä½ç½®ï¼Œè®©ä½ è¾“å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªé•¿åº¦å°äº 2nm çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼ˆåªåŒ…æ‹¬U,D,L,Rï¼Œè¡¨ç¤ºç§»åŠ¨çš„æ–¹å‘ï¼Œå½“ç§»åŠ¨åˆ°è¾¹ç•Œæ—¶å°±åŸåœ°ä¸åŠ¨ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ§åˆ¶æ‰€æœ‰çš„kä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œè®©æ¯ä¸ªç‚¹éƒ½ä¼šè‡³å°‘ç»è¿‡ä¸€æ¬¡è‡ªå·±å¯¹åº”çš„ç»ˆæ­¢ç‚¹ã€‚ è¿™é“é¢˜æ²¡æœ‰è¦æ±‚è¾“å‡ºæœ€å°çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥è®©æ‰€æœ‰çš„èµ·å§‹ç‚¹éƒ½ç½®äºçŸ©é˜µçš„å·¦ä¸Šè§’ï¼Œç„¶åä»å·¦ä¸Šè§’å¼€å§‹ï¼Œåˆ°å³ä¸‹è§’ï¼Œä¾æ¬¡è®¿é—®çŸ©é˜µçš„æ¯ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œ #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define fi first #define se second #define pb push_back #define PI acos(-1) #define LC(a) ((a<<1)) #define RC(a) ((a<<1)+1) #define MID(a,b) ((a+b)>>1) #define mem(a, b) memset(a, b, sizeof(a)) #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; typedef unsigned long long ULL; typedef pair<int,int> PII; typedef pair<ll,ll> PLL; typedef pair<ll,int> PLI; const int INF = 0X3F3F3F3F; const int MIN = -(1<<30); const ll N = 1e5+7; inline void solve() { int n,m,k; cin>>n>>m>>k; int x,y; for(int i=0; i<k; i++) cin>>x>>y;//ä¸è¾“å…¥çš„èµ·å§‹ç‚¹å’Œç»ˆæ­¢ç‚¹æ— å…³äº† for(int i=0; i<k; i++) cin>>x>>y; string s=""; for(int i=n; i>1; i--) s=s+'U';//æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰ç‚¹å‘ä¸Šå‘å·¦ç§»åˆ°å·¦ä¸Šè§’ for(int j=m; j>1; j--) s=s+'L'; for(int i=1; i<=n; i++)//nè¡Œ { if(i&1) //å¥‡æ•°è¡Œå‘å³ for(int j=1; j<m; j++) s=s+'R'; else //å¶æ•°è¡Œå‘å·¦ for(int j=m; j>1; j--) s=s+'L'; if(i!=n) s+='D'; //é™¤äº†æœ€åä¸€è¡Œ æ¯è¡Œèµ°åˆ°å¤´çš„æ—¶å€™å‘ä¸‹ } cout<<s.size()<<endl<<s<<endl; } int main() { IOS(); solve(); return 0; } E. Count The BlocksYou wrote down all integers from 0 to 10n âˆ’ 1, padding them with leading zeroes so their lengths are exactly n. For example, if n = 3 then you wrote out 000, 001, â€¦, 998, 999. A block in an integer x is a consecutive segment of equal digits that cannot be extended to the left or to the right. For example, in the integer 00027734000 there are three blocks of length 1, one block of length 2 and two blocks of length 3. For all integers i from 1 to n count the number of blocks of length i among the written down integers. Since these integers may be too large, print them modulo 998244353. InputThe only line contains one integer n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 2â‹…105). OutputIn the only line print n integers. The i-th integer is equal to the number of blocks of length i. Since these integers may be too large, print them modulo 998244353. Examplesinput 1 output 10 input 2 output 180 10 Problem solvingé¢˜æ„è®©æ±‚çš„æ˜¯ä» 0 åˆ° 10n - 1çš„è¿™äº›æ•°ä¸­ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬å‰å¯¼0ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥éƒ½æ˜¯nä½æ•°ï¼‰ï¼Œ å¯¹åº”çš„æ¯ä¸ªé•¿åº¦iä¸€å…±æœ‰å¤šå°‘ä¸ªblockã€‚ blockæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯è¿ç»­ç›¸åŒçš„æ•°å­—çš„é•¿åº¦ï¼Œæ— æ³•å‘å·¦å‘å³æ‰©å±•ã€‚ ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š00027734000æœ‰2ä¸ªé•¿åº¦ä¸º3çš„blockï¼Œ1ä¸ªé•¿åº¦ä¸º2çš„blockï¼Œ3ä¸ªé•¿åº¦ä¸º1çš„block. å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºç°åœ¨æœ‰nä¸ªç©ºï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªç©ºéƒ½å¯ä»¥æ’å…¥0-9çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰è¿™äº›æ’åˆ—ä¸­é•¿åº¦ä¸ºiçš„blockæœ‰å¤šå°‘ä¸ªã€‚ å› ä¸ºæ‰€æ±‚çš„æ˜¯é•¿åº¦ä¸ºiçš„blockï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸å¦¨ç›´æ¥æ’å…¥ä¸€æ®µé•¿åº¦ä¸ºiçš„è¿ç»­ç›¸ç­‰çš„ä¸€ä¸²æ•°å­—ï¼Œç„¶åå¤„ç†è¿™ä¸²æ•°å­—ä¸¤ç«¯ç›¸é‚»çš„ä½ç½®ï¼Œè®©ä»–ä»¬ä¸ä¸æ’å…¥çš„æ•°å­—ç›¸ç­‰å³å¯ã€‚è¿™é‡Œåˆ†ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µï¼š [ ] æ’å…¥çš„ä¸²ä¸¤ç«¯éƒ½ä¸åœ¨è¾¹ç•Œï¼Œæ’å…¥çš„è¿ç»­ä¸²å¯ä»¥ä¸º0-9ï¼Œ10ç§ï¼Œä¸¤ç«¯ç›¸é‚»çš„ä½ç½®ä¸èƒ½å’Œä»–ç›¸åŒï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æœ‰9ç§ã€‚å…¶ä»–çš„ä½ç½®å¯ä»¥éšä¾¿ï¼Œéƒ½æ˜¯10ç§ã€‚è€Œé•¿åº¦ä¸ºiçš„ä¸²åœ¨nä¸ªä¸ºä½ç½®ä¸­æœ‰ï¼ˆn-i+1ï¼‰ä¸ªä½ç½®å¯ä»¥æŸ¥å…¥ï¼Œå‡å»ä¸¤ç«¯çš„è¾¹ç•Œï¼Œå°±æœ‰ï¼ˆn-i-1)ä¸ªä½ç½®å¯ä»¥æ’å…¥ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥ä¸€å…±æœ‰ï¼š(n-i-1)$\times$10$\times$9$\times$9$\times$10 n-i-2 ä¸ªblockï¼Œn-i-2æ˜¯å‰©ä½™éšä¾¿æ’çš„ç©ºæ ¼ã€‚ [ ] æ’å…¥çš„ä¸²ä¸¤ç«¯æœ‰ä¸€ç«¯åœ¨è¾¹ç•Œã€‚å› ä¸ºæœ‰ä¸€ç«¯åœ¨è¾¹ç•Œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åªéœ€è¦å¤„ç†å¦ä¸€ç«¯ä¸åœ¨è¾¹ç•Œçš„ç›¸é‚»ä½ç½®å°±è¡Œäº†ã€‚è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µæœ‰ 2$\times$10$\times$9$\times$10 n-i-1 ä¸ªblockï¼Œè¿™é‡Œä¹˜ä¸Š2æ˜¯å› ä¸ºæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªè¾¹ç•Œï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“å“ªä¸€ç«¯åœ¨è¾¹ç•Œä¸Šã€‚ è¿™ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µåŠ èµ·æ¥å°±æ˜¯æ‰€æ±‚çš„blockçš„ä¸ªæ•°äº† #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define fi first #define se second #define pb push_back #define PI acos(-1) #define LC(a) ((a<<1)) #define RC(a) ((a<<1)+1) #define MID(a,b) ((a+b)>>1) #define mem(a, b) memset(a, b, sizeof(a)) #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; typedef unsigned long long ULL; typedef pair<int,int> PII; typedef pair<ll,ll> PLL; typedef pair<ll,int> PLI; const int INF = 0X3F3F3F3F; const int MIN = -(1<<30); const ll N = 2e5+7; const ll mod = 998244353; ll fac[N]; ll ans[N]; inline void solve() { fac[0]=1; for(int i=1; i<N; i++) fac[i] = fac[i-1]*10%mod; //æŠŠ10çš„Næ¬¡æ–¹é¢„å¤„ç†ä¸€ä¸‹ ll n; cin>>n; ans[n] = 10; for(int i=n-1; i>=1; i--) ans[i] = (((n-i-1)*10*9*9*fac[n-i-2])%mod + (10*9*2*fac[n-i-1])%mod)%mod; for(int i=1; i<=n; i++) cout<<ans[i]<<" "; cout<<endl; } int main() { IOS(); solve(); return 0; }

posts.title: Codeforces Round #627 (Div. 3) Dã€E
posts.text: D. Pair of TopicsThe next lecture in a high school requires two topics to be discussed. The i-th topic is interesting by ai units for the teacher and by bi units for the students. The pair of topics i and j (i < j) is called good if ai + aj > bi + bj (i.e. it is more interesting for the teacher). Your task is to find the number of good pairs of topics. InputThe first line of the input contains one integer n (2 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 2â‹…105) â€” the number of topics. The second line of the input contains n integers a1,a2,â€¦,an (1 â‰¤ ai â‰¤ 109), where ai is the interestingness of the i-th topic for the teacher. The third line of the input contains n integers b1,b2,â€¦,bn (1 â‰¤ bi â‰¤ 109), where bi is the interestingness of the i-th topic for the students. OutputPrint one integer â€” the number of good pairs of topic. Examplesinput 5 4 8 2 6 2 4 5 4 1 3 output 7 input 4 1 3 2 4 1 3 2 4 output 0 Problem solvingé¢˜æ„å°±æ˜¯è®©ä½ é€‰å‡ºä¸¤ä¸ªä¸‹æ ‡i , jï¼Œæ±‚ç¬¦åˆai + aj > bi + bj çš„æœ‰å¤šå°‘å¯¹ã€‚ å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥è®©aå‡å»bä¸­ä¸‹æ ‡ç›¸ç­‰çš„å€¼ï¼Œç„¶åä»å¤§åˆ°å°æ’åºã€‚ è¿™æ ·å°±å˜æˆä»ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ç»„ä¸­æŒ‘é€‰ä¸¤ä¸ªæ•°å’Œå¤§äº0çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚ å› ä¸ºåªé€‰äº†ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸‹æ ‡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åªéœ€è¦å…ˆé€‰ä¸€ä¸ªï¼Œå¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªç”¨äºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾å°±å¯ä»¥äº†ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; const ll N = 2e5+7; ll a[N]; ll cmp(ll a,ll b) { return a>b; } inline void solve() { int n; cin>>n; for(int i=0;i<n;i++) cin>>a[i]; for(int i=0;i<n;i++) { ll x;cin>>x; a[i]-=x; } sort(a,a+n,cmp); ll ans = 0; for(int i=0;i<n;i++) { if(a[i]<=0) break; int l=i,r=n-1; while(l<r) { int mid = (l+r+1)/2; if(a[i]+a[mid]<=0) r=mid-1; else l = mid; } ans += l-i; } cout<<ans<<endl; } int main() { IOS(); solve(); return 0; } E. Sleeping ScheduleVova had a pretty weird sleeping schedule. There are h hours in a day. Vova will sleep exactly n times. The ii-th time he will sleep exactly after ai hours from the time he woke up. You can assume that Vova woke up exactly at the beginning of this story (the initial time is 00). Each time Vova sleeps exactly one day (in other words, h hours). Vova thinks that the ii-th sleeping time is good if he starts to sleep between hours l and r inclusive. Vova can control himself and before the ii-th time can choose between two options: go to sleep after ai hours or after ai âˆ’ 1 hours. Your task is to say the maximum number of good sleeping times Vova can obtain if he acts optimally. InputThe first line of the input contains four integers n,h,l and r (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 2000,3 â‰¤ h â‰¤ 2000,0 â‰¤ l â‰¤ r < h) â€” the number of times Vova goes to sleep, the number of hours in a day and the segment of the good sleeping time. The second line of the input contains n integers a1,a2,â€¦,an(1 â‰¤ ai < h), where ai is the number of hours after which Vova goes to sleep the ii-th time. OutputPrint one integer â€” the maximum number of good sleeping times Vova can obtain if he acts optimally. Exampleinput 7 24 21 23 16 17 14 20 20 11 22 output 3 Problem solvingé¢˜æ„æ˜¯è¯´è§„å®šä¸€å¤©æœ‰hå°æ—¶ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡ç¡è§‰éƒ½å¯ä»¥æ§åˆ¶ç¡aiæˆ–è€…ai-1å°æ—¶ï¼Œç»è¿‡næ¬¡åæœ€å¤šæœ‰å¤šå°‘æ¬¡é†’æ¥çš„æ—¶é—´åœ¨ [l, r] åŒºé—´å†…ã€‚ DP å¾…è¡¥ï¼

posts.title: Codeforces Round #622 (Div. 2)
posts.text: A. Fast Food RestaurantTired of boring office work, Denis decided to open a fast food restaurant. On the first day he made a portions of dumplings, b portions of cranberry juice and c pancakes with condensed milk. The peculiarity of Denisâ€™s restaurant is the procedure of ordering food. For each visitor Denis himself chooses a set of dishes that this visitor will receive. When doing so, Denis is guided by the following rules: every visitor should receive at least one dish (dumplings, cranberry juice, pancakes with condensed milk are all considered to be dishes); each visitor should receive no more than one portion of dumplings, no more than one portion of cranberry juice and no more than one pancake with condensed milk; all visitors should receive different sets of dishes. What is the maximum number of visitors Denis can feed? InputThe first line contains an integer t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 500) â€” the number of test cases to solve. Each of the remaining t lines contains integers a, b and c (0 â‰¤ a,b,c â‰¤ 10) â€” the number of portions of dumplings, the number of portions of cranberry juice and the number of condensed milk pancakes Denis made. OutputFor each test case print a single integer â€” the maximum number of visitors Denis can feed. Exampleinput7 1 2 1 0 0 0 9 1 7 2 2 3 2 3 2 3 2 2 4 4 4 output3 0 4 5 5 5 7 NoteIn the first test case of the example, Denis can feed the first visitor with dumplings, give the second a portion of cranberry juice, and give the third visitor a portion of cranberry juice and a pancake with a condensed milk. In the second test case of the example, the restaurant Denis is not very promising: he can serve no customers. In the third test case of the example, Denise can serve four visitors. The first guest will receive a full lunch of dumplings, a portion of cranberry juice and a pancake with condensed milk. The second visitor will get only dumplings. The third guest will receive a pancake with condensed milk, and the fourth guest will receive a pancake and a portion of dumplings. Please note that Denis hasnâ€™t used all of the prepared products, but is unable to serve more visitors. Problem solving:é¢˜æ„å°±æ˜¯æœ‰ä¸‰ç§ä¸åŒçš„é£Ÿç‰©ï¼Œç»™å‡ºä¸‰ç§é£Ÿç‰©çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œé—®æœ‰å¤šå°‘ç§é£Ÿç‰©æ­é…çš„æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼ˆå¯ä»¥ç”¨1ç§ã€2ç§æˆ–3ç§é£Ÿç‰©è¿›è¡Œæ­é…ï¼Œåªè¦æ²¡å‡ºç°è¿‡å°±å¯ä»¥ï¼‰ã€‚ å¾ˆæ˜æ˜¾å…ˆä»åªé€‰1ç§é£Ÿç‰©å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå¦‚æœå½“å‰æ•°é‡å¤§äº1ï¼Œæ–¹æ¡ˆæ•°å°±åŠ ä¸€ã€‚ ç„¶åä»2ç§é£Ÿç‰©å¼€å§‹æ­é…ï¼Œä¼˜å…ˆè´ªå¿ƒé€‰æ‹©å‰©ä½™æ•°é‡æœ€å¤šçš„ä¸¤ç§ï¼Œç„¶åå†ä¹±æï¼ˆä¸¤ä¸¤é€‰æ‹©ï¼‰ã€‚ æœ€åå¦‚æœ3ç§é£Ÿç‰©æ•°é‡éƒ½å¤§äº1ï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥å†åŠ ä¸€ç§æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼ˆé€‰æ‹©ä¸‰ç§é£Ÿç‰©ï¼‰ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; const ll N = 1e5+7; int main() { int t; cin>>t; while(t--) { int a,b,c; cin>>a>>b>>c; int ans=0; if(a>0) a--,ans++; if(b>0) b--,ans++; if(c>0) c--,ans++; int k[3]; k[0]=a; k[1]=b; k[2]=c; sort(k,k+3); if(k[2]>0 && k[1]>0) k[2]--,k[1]--,ans++;//å…ˆé€‰æ‹©æœ€å¤šçš„ä¸¤ä¸ª //ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯ä¹±æçš„ if(k[0]>0 && k[2]>0) k[0]--,k[2]--,ans++; if(k[1]>0 && k[0]>0) k[1]--,k[0]--,ans++; if(k[1]>0 && k[0]>0 && k[2]>0) ans++; cout<<ans<<endl; } return 0; } B. Different RulesNikolay has only recently started in competitive programming, but already qualified to the finals of one prestigious Olympiad. There going to be n participants, one of whom is Nikolay. Like any good Olympiad, it consists of two rounds. Tired of the traditional rules, in which the participant who solved the largest number of problems wins, the organizers came up with different rules. Suppose in the first round participant A took x-th place and in the second round â€” y-th place. Then the total score of the participant A is sum x + y. The overall place of the participant A is the number of participants (including A) having their total score less than or equal to the total score of A. Note, that some participants may end up having a common overall place. It is also important to note, that in both the first and the second round there were no two participants tying at a common place. In other words, for every i from 1 to n exactly one participant took i-th place in first round and exactly one participant took i-th place in second round. Right after the end of the Olympiad, Nikolay was informed that he got x-th place in first round and y-th place in the second round. Nikolay doesnâ€™t know the results of other participants, yet he wonders what is the minimum and maximum place he can take, if we consider the most favorable and unfavorable outcome for him. Please help Nikolay to find the answer to this question. InputThe first line contains an integer t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 100) â€” the number of test cases to solve. Each of the following t lines contains integers n, x, y (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 109, 1 â‰¤ x, y â‰¤ n) â€” the number of participants in the Olympiad, the place that Nikolay took in the first round and the place that Nikolay took in the second round. OutputPrint two integers â€” the minimum and maximum possible overall place Nikolay could take. Examplesinput1 5 1 3 output1 3 input1 6 3 4 output2 6 Problem solving:é¢˜æ„æ˜¯è¯´ä¸€å…±æœ‰nä¸ªäººï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤è½®æ¯”èµ›ï¼Œä½ ç¬¬ä¸€è½®å¾—äº†ç¬¬aåã€‚ç¬¬äºŒè½®å¾—äº†ç¬¬båã€‚æœ€åçš„æ€»åæ¬¡æ˜¯æŒ‰ç…§è¿™ä¸¤æ¬¡æ¯”èµ›å’Œåæ¬¡å’Œæ¥åˆ¤æ–­çš„ï¼Œä¸¤è½®çš„åæ¬¡å’Œè¶Šå°‘æ€»åæ¬¡è¶Šé«˜ï¼Œé—®å·²çŸ¥n,a,bçš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæœ€å¥½ã€æœ€åèƒ½å¾—å¤šå°‘åã€‚ æ³¨æ„ä¸¤è½®æ¯”èµ›ä¸­æ²¡æœ‰ä¸¤äººåæ¬¡ç›¸åŒçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œæ€»åæ¬¡ä¼šæœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚5ä¸ªäººåæ¬¡å’Œåˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ 4ï¼Œ4ï¼Œ4ï¼Œ8ï¼Œ10ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™äº”ä¸ªäººçš„æ€»åæ¬¡å°±æ˜¯3, 3, 3, 4, 5ã€‚ æœ€åæƒ…å†µå°±æ˜¯æ€»åæ¬¡åœ¨ä½ å‰é¢çš„äººä¸¤è½®çš„åæ¬¡å’Œéƒ½å’Œä½ ç›¸åŒï¼Œè¿™æ ·æœ€å¤šä¼šæœ‰a+b-1äººï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬è‡ªå·±ï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œæœ€å¤šåªæœ‰näººæ‰€ä»¥æœ€åæƒ…å†µå°±æ˜¯min(n,a+b-1); è‡³äºæœ€å¥½æƒ…å†µï¼Œæ„Ÿè§‰ï¼ˆä¹±æï¼‰å‡ºæ¥çš„ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; int main() { int t; cin>>t; while(t--) { ll n,x,y; cin>>n>>x>>y; ll sum = x+y; //æœ€å¥½ if(sum<n) cout<<1<<" "; else cout<<min(n,sum-n+1)<<" "; //æœ€å cout<<min(n,sum-1)<<endl; } return 0; } C1. Skyscrapers (easy version)This is an easier version of the problem. In this version n â‰¤ 1000 The outskirts of the capital are being actively built up in Berland. The company â€œKernel Panicâ€ manages the construction of a residential complex of skyscrapers in New Berlskva. All skyscrapers are built along the highway. It is known that the company has already bought n plots along the highway and is preparing to build n skyscrapers, one skyscraper per plot. Architects must consider several requirements when planning a skyscraper. Firstly, since the land on each plot has different properties, each skyscraper has a limit on the largest number of floors it can have. Secondly, according to the design code of the city, it is unacceptable for a skyscraper to simultaneously have higher skyscrapers both to the left and to the right of it. Formally, letâ€™s number the plots from 1 to n. Then if the skyscraper on the i-th plot has ai floors, it must hold that ai is at most mi (1 â‰¤ ai â‰¤ mi). Also there mustnâ€™t be integers j and k such that j < i < k and aj > ai < ak . Plots j and k are not required to be adjacent to i. The company wants the total number of floors in the built skyscrapers to be as large as possible. Help it to choose the number of floors for each skyscraper in an optimal way, i.e. in such a way that all requirements are fulfilled, and among all such construction plans choose any plan with the maximum possible total number of floors. InputThe first line contains a single integer n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 1000) â€” the number of plots. The second line contains the integers m1,m2,â€¦,mn (1 â‰¤ mi â‰¤ 109) â€” the limit on the number of floors for every possible number of floors for a skyscraper on each plot. OutputPrint n integers ai â€” the number of floors in the plan for each skyscraper, such that all requirements are met, and the total number of floors in all skyscrapers is the maximum possible. If there are multiple answers possible, print any of them. Examplesinput5 1 2 3 2 1 output1 2 3 2 1 input3 10 6 8 output10 6 6 NoteIn the first example, you can build all skyscrapers with the highest possible height. In the second test example, you cannot give the maximum height to all skyscrapers as this violates the design code restriction. The answer [10,6,6] is optimal. Note that the answer of [6,6,8] also satisfies all restrictions, but is not optimal. Problem solving:é¢˜æ„æ˜¯è¯´ç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ªåºåˆ—ï¼Œè®©ä½ ä¿®æ”¹æˆ j < i < k æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ²¡æœ‰ aj > ai < ak çš„åºåˆ—ï¼Œè¦æ±‚ä¿®æ”¹åçš„åºåˆ—å’Œæœ€å¤§ã€‚ä¿®æ”¹æ—¶æ¯ä¸ªæ•°ä¸èƒ½è¶…è¿‡åŸæ¥çš„å¤§å°ã€‚ è¿™é“é¢˜å› ä¸ºæ˜¯easyç‰ˆæœ¬çš„ ï¼Œæ•°æ®èŒƒå›´æ¯”è¾ƒå°ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬æƒ…å†µä¸‹å°±å¯ä»¥ç”¨æš´åŠ›ã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¦æš´åŠ›æ£€æŸ¥æ¯ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼ŒæŠŠå½“å‰ç‚¹å½“åšæœ€å¤§çš„ï¼Œä¾æ¬¡å¾€ä¸¤è¾¹æ‰«å°±å¯ä»¥äº†ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define fi first #define se second #define PI acos(-1) #define LC(a) ((a<<1)) #define RC(a) ((a<<1)+1) #define MID(a,b) ((a+b)>>1) #define mem(a, b) memset(a, b, sizeof(a)) #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; typedef unsigned long long ULL; typedef pair<int,int> PII; typedef pair<ll,ll> PLL; typedef pair<ll,int> PLI; const int INF = 0X3F3F3F3F; const int MIN = -(1<<30); const ll N = 1e5+7; int main() { IOS(); int n; cin>>n; ll a[1005]; ll b[1005]; ll c[1005]; ll mxi=0; for(int i=0; i<n; i++) cin>>a[i]; ll ans=0; ll num; for(int mxi=0;mxi<n;mxi++) { num = a[mxi]; b[mxi] = a[mxi]; for(int i=mxi-1; i>=0; i--) { if(a[i]>b[i+1]) b[i]=b[i+1]; else b[i] = a[i]; num+=b[i]; } for(int i=mxi+1; i<n; i++) { if(a[i]>b[i-1]) b[i]=b[i-1]; else b[i] = a[i]; num+=b[i]; } if(ans<num) { ans=num; for(int i=0; i<n; i++) c[i]=b[i]; } } for(int i=0; i<n; i++) cout<<c[i]<<" "; cout<<endl; return 0; } C2. Skyscrapers (hard version)è¿™é“é¢˜å’ŒC1æ˜¯ä¸€æ¨¡ä¸€æ ·çš„ï¼Œåªæ˜¯nä»1000å¢åŠ åˆ°äº†500 000ã€‚ å¾…è¡¥ï¼

return 0; } è‡ªå·±äºŒåˆ†å†™çš„ä¸ç†Ÿï¼Œæ¯”èµ›ä¸­ä¸€ç›´waï¼Œæä¸æ‡‚å“ªé‡Œé”™äº†ï¼Œæœ€åç”¨äº†STLé‡Œçš„äºŒåˆ†å‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯waã€‚ ç„¶åæ— æ„çš„æŠŠans*=(k-i>0?k-i:0)%mod æ”¹æˆäº† ans=ans*(k-i>0?k-i:0)%mod ä¸€ä¸‹å°±ACäº†ï¼Œè¿ç®—ç¬¦ä¼˜å…ˆçº§çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œç™¾åº¦äº†ä¸€ä¸‹çœ‹åˆ° *=çš„ä¼˜å…ˆçº§è¦æ¯” % ä¼˜å…ˆçº§å°å¾—å¤šï¼Œä¸‹æ¬¡ä¸ä¼šå†å·æ‡’äº†ã€‚

posts.text: C.å­æ®µä¹˜ç§¯ç»™å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªé•¿åº¦ä¸º n çš„æ•°åˆ— a 1ï¼Œ a 2ï¼Œa 3 . . . a nï¼Œæ±‚å…¶é•¿åº¦ä¸º k çš„è¿ç»­å­æ®µçš„ä¹˜ç§¯å¯¹ 998244353 å–æ¨¡ä½™æ•°çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼ã€‚ è¾“å…¥æè¿°ç¬¬ä¸€è¡Œä¸¤ä¸ªæ•´æ•°n,kã€‚ ç¬¬äºŒè¡Œnä¸ªæ•´æ•°,a 1ï¼Œ a 2ï¼Œa 3 . . . a nã€‚ 1 <= k <= n <= 2e5 0 <= ai < 998244353 è¾“å‡ºæè¿°è¾“å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªæ•´æ•°ï¼Œä»£è¡¨æœ€å¤§ä½™æ•°ã€‚ ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼šè¾“å…¥5 3 1 2 3 0 8 è¾“å‡º6 è¯´æ˜1âˆ—2âˆ—3 mod 998244353 = 6 é¢˜è§£é¢˜æ„å¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œæ±‚çš„æ˜¯åŒºé—´ä¸ºkçš„æ‰€æœ‰æ•°ä¹‹ç§¯ mod 998244353 çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼æ˜¯å¤šå°‘ã€‚æš´åŠ›æ€è·¯åªç”¨å°†æ‰€æœ‰é•¿åº¦ä¸ºkçš„åŒºé—´è®¡ç®—ä¸€éçºªå½•æœ€å¤§å€¼å°±è¡Œäº†ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸ºOï¼ˆ(n-k)*kï¼‰, å·®ä¸å¤šå°±æ˜¯Oï¼ˆn2)ã€‚ å¿…ç„¶ä¼šè¶…æ—¶ã€‚ æ­£ç¡®åšæ³•æ˜¯ç”¨çº¿æ®µæ ‘å‚¨å­˜æ¯ä¸ªæ•°ï¼Œçº¿æ®µæ ‘æŸ¥è¯¢çš„æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦Oï¼ˆlogn) ï¼Œæ€»ä½“æ¥è¯´å°±æ˜¯Oï¼ˆnlogn)ã€‚ è¿™é“é¢˜ä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰ä¿®æ”¹ä»€ä¹ˆçš„ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦å»ºæ ‘ï¼Œæš´åŠ›åŒºé—´æŸ¥è¯¢å°±å¯ä»¥äº†ã€‚ #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define LC(a) ((a<<1)) #define RC(a) ((a<<1)+1) #define MID(a,b) ((a+b)>>1) #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; const ll N = 2e5+7; const ll mod = 998244353; ll mx[N*4]; void build(int node,int l,int r) { if(l==r) { int x; cin>>x; mx[node]=x;//å½“æ•°åˆ°è¾¾å¶å­èŠ‚ç‚¹è¾“å…¥å­˜å…¥å€¼ return; } int mid = MID(l,r); build(LC(node),l,mid); build(RC(node),mid+1,r); mx[node] = mx[LC(node)] * mx[RC(node)] % mod;//çˆ¶èŠ‚ç‚¹æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªå­èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„ä¹˜ç§¯ mod 998244353 } ll query(int node,int st,int end,int l,int r) { if(end < l || st > r) return 1l; //å¦‚æœé€’å½’åˆ°çš„åŒºé—´ä¸æŸ¥è¯¢åŒºé—´æ²¡æœ‰é‡åˆéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œè¿”å›1ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºæ˜¯ä¹˜ç§¯ï¼‰ if(st >= l && end <= r) return mx[node];//å¦‚æœé€’å½’åˆ°çš„åŒºé—´å®Œå…¨è¢«æŸ¥è¯¢åŒºé—´åŒ…å«ï¼Œè¿”å›å½“å‰ç»“ç‚¹çš„å€¼ ll lsum = query(LC(node),st,MID(st,end),l,r);//éå†å·¦å­æ ‘ ll rsum = query(RC(node),MID(st,end)+1,end,l,r);//éå†å³å­æ ‘ return lsum*rsum%mod;// } int main() { IOS(); int n,k; cin>>n>>k; build(1,1,n);//å»ºæ ‘ ll ans = 0; for(int i=1,j=k;j<=n;j++,i++) //å°ºå–æ¯ä¸ªé•¿åº¦ä¸ºkçš„åŒºé—´ ans = max(ans,query(1,1,n,i,j)); cout<<ans<<endl; return 0; }

posts.title: Educational Codeforces Round 81 (Rated for Div. 2) B. Infinite Prefixes
posts.text: B. Infinite PrefixesYou are given string s of length n consisting of 0-s and 1-s. You build an infinite string t as a concatenation of an infinite number of strings s, or t = ssssâ€¦ For example, if s = 10010, then t= 100101001010010... Calculate the number of prefixes of t with balance equal to x. The balance of some string q is equal to cnt0,q âˆ’ cnt1,q, where cnt0,q is the number of occurrences of 0 in q, and cnt1,q is the number of occurrences of 1 in q. The number of such prefixes can be infinite; if it is so, you must say that. A prefix is a string consisting of several first letters of a given string, without any reorders. An empty prefix is also a valid prefix. For example, the string â€œabcdâ€œ has 5 prefixes: empty string, â€œaâ€œ, â€œabâ€œ, â€œabcâ€œ and â€œabcdâ€œ. InputThe first line contains the single integer T (1 â‰¤ T â‰¤ 100)â€” the number of test cases. Next 2T lines contain descriptions of test cases â€” two lines per test case. The first line contains two integers n and x (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 105, âˆ’109 â‰¤ x â‰¤ 109) â€” the length of string s and the desired balance, respectively. The second line contains the binary string s (|s| = n, si âˆˆ {0,1}). Itâ€™s guaranteed that the total sum of n doesnâ€™t exceed 105. OutputPrint T integers â€” one per test case. For each test case print the number of prefixes or âˆ’1 if there is an infinite number of such prefixes. Exampleinput4 6 10 010010 5 3 10101 1 0 0 2 0 01 output3 0 1 -1 NoteIn the first test case, there are 3 good prefixes of t: with length 28, 30 and 32. Problem solving:è¿™åœºcfå…¨æ˜¯å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œç›´æ¥è‡ªé—­ã€‚ é¢˜ç›®æ„æ€æ˜¯ç»™ä½ ä¸€ä¸ª01å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œç„¶åè¿™ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¯ä»¥æ— é™å åŠ ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚010010å¯ä»¥å˜æˆ010010 010010ã€010010 010010 010010 010010 010010ï¼ˆä¸²ä¸­æ²¡æœ‰ç©ºæ ¼ï¼‰ â€¦ ã€‚ç„¶åæ‰¾è¿™ä¸ªæ— é™å­—ç¬¦ä¸²çš„å‰ç¼€ï¼Œå‰ç¼€0çš„ä¸ªæ•°å‡å»1çš„ä¸ªæ•°ç­‰äºxã€‚é—®æœ‰å¤šå°‘ç§ç¬¦åˆçš„å‰ç¼€ã€‚ å› ä¸ºxæœ‰æ­£è´Ÿä¹‹åˆ†ï¼Œéœ€è¦åˆ¤æ–­çš„å¤ªå¤šäº†ï¼Œç„¶åå°±æŠŠè‡ªå·±ç»•è¿›å»äº†ã€‚çœ‹äº†åˆ«äººçš„ä»£ç åæ‰çŸ¥é“å¯ä»¥å…ˆæŠŠè´Ÿæ•°çš„ x å˜æˆæ­£æ•°ï¼Œç„¶åæŠŠåŸä¸²01å¯¹æ¢ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±åªéœ€è¦åˆ¤æ–­æ­£æ•°çš„xäº†ã€‚ æŠŠåŸä¸² cnt0,q âˆ’ cnt1,q è®°ä¸º numã€‚ å› ä¸ºä¸²æ˜¯æ— ç©·çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¼šå‡ºç°æœ‰æ— ç©·å¤šä¸ªè§£çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚å½“åŸä¸² num ç­‰äº 0 ï¼ŒåŸä¸²å‰ç¼€çš„cnt0,q âˆ’ cnt1,qç­‰äºx æ—¶ï¼Œç­”æ¡ˆå°±æœ‰æ— ç©·å¤šä¸ªã€‚è¾“å‡º -1 å½“ num ä¸ä¸º 0 æ—¶ æˆ‘ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°ç»„aè®°å½•åŸä¸²ä¸­å‰ç¼€å½“å‰ä½ç½®çš„ cnt0,i âˆ’ cnt1,i ,å¦‚ä¸‹è¡¨æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š s = 010010 , x = 10 ç„¶åéå†è¿™ä¸ªæ•°ç»„ï¼Œå½“ ( x - a[i] ) % num == 0 && ( x - a[i] ) / num >= 0 ï¼‰ æ—¶ ç­”æ¡ˆanså°±+1ï¼› å¦‚è¡¨ä¸­ ä¸‹æ ‡ä¸º2æ—¶ ï¼Œa[1] = 0ï¼Œ( x - a[i] ) % num == 0ï¼› ( x - a[i] ) / num = 5 ã€‚è¯´æ˜å‰ç¼€åŒ…å«äº†äº”ä¸ªåŸä¸²ä¸­ï¼Œå†åŠ ä¸Šç¬¬å…­ä¸ªåŸä¸²çš„å‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå°±å¯ä»¥æ»¡è¶³ cnt0,q âˆ’ cnt1,q = 10 å½“å‰ä½ç½®ä¸º 5 * 6 + 2 å³ 32ã€‚ å½“ä¸‹æ ‡ä¸º4æ—¶ï¼Œ ( x - a[i] ) / num = 4 ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°åœ¨ä½ç½® 4 * 6 + 4 å³ 28 å¤„æ‰¾åˆ°è§£ã€‚ å½“ä¸‹æ ‡ä¸º6æ—¶ï¼Œ ( x - a[i] ) / num = 4 ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°åœ¨ä½ç½® 4 * 6 + 6 å³ 30 å¤„æ‰¾åˆ°è§£ã€‚ ç¬¦åˆæ ·ä¾‹ä¸€ã€‚ ACä»£ç ï¼š #include<bits/stdc++.h> #define fi first #define se second #define PI acos(-1) #define LC(a) ((a<<1)) #define RC(a) ((a<<1)+1) #define MID(a,b) ((a+b)>>1) #define mem(a, b) memset(a, b, sizeof(a)) #define IOS() std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false),cin.tie(0),cout.tie(0) using namespace std; typedef long long ll; typedef unsigned long long ULL; typedef pair<int,int> PII; typedef pair<ll,ll> PLL; typedef pair<ll,int> PLI; const int INF = 0X3F3F3F3F; const int MIN = -(1<<30); const ll N = 1e6+7; ll a[N]; int main() { IOS(); int t; cin>>t; while(t--) { ll n,x; string s; cin>>n>>x>>s; if(x<0) { x=-x; for(int i=0; i<n; i++) s[i]=s[i]=='0'?'1':'0'; } // cout<<s<<endl; ll num=0; for(int i=0; i<s.size(); i++) { if(s[i]=='0') num++; else num--; a[i]=num; } ll ans=0; int flag = 0; if(num==0) { for(int i=0; i<n; i++) { if(a[i]==x) flag=1; } } else { for(int i=0; i<n; i++) { if((x-a[i])%num==0 && (x-a[i])/num>=0) ans++; } } if(x==0) ans++; if(flag) cout<<-1<<endl; else cout<<ans<<endl; } return 0; } è¡¥é¢˜è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­æˆ‘è¾“å‡º -1 ç”¨äº† puts,å¯¼è‡´äº†ä¸æ–­åœ° Wrong answer on test 4 ï¼Œç™¾åº¦åæ‰çŸ¥é“ å…³é—­åŒæ­¥æµ (std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false) )ä¹‹å,ä¸èƒ½å†ä½¿ç”¨ scanf ã€printfã€getsã€puts â€¦ã€‚æ˜¨å¤©æœ‰ä¸€é“é¢˜æ¢è¡Œç”¨äº†endlä¹Ÿå¯¼è‡´äº†waï¼Œæ”¹ç”¨ â€˜\nâ€™ å°± ac,éš¾å—äº†æˆ‘å¥½é•¿æ—¶é—´ã€‚æˆ‘å†³å®šä»¥åæ…¢æ…¢åœ°æ”¾å¼ƒcinã€coutã€‚ è™½ç„¶å®ƒå¾ˆé¦™ã€‚

posts.title: Codeforces Round #608 (Div. 2) B. Blocks
posts.text: B. BlocksThere are n blocks arranged in a row and numbered from left to right, starting from one. Each block is either black or white. You may perform the following operation zero or more times: choose two adjacent blocks and invert their colors (white block becomes black, and vice versa). You want to find a sequence of operations, such that they make all the blocks having the same color. You donâ€™t have to minimize the number of operations, but it should not exceed 3 â‹… n. If it is impossible to find such a sequence of operations, you need to report it. InputThe first line contains one integer n (2 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 200) â€” the number of blocks. The second line contains one string s consisting of n characters, each character is either â€œWâ€ or â€œBâ€. If the i-th character is â€œWâ€, then the i-th block is white. If the i-th character is â€œBâ€, then the i-th block is black. OutputIf it is impossible to make all the blocks having the same color, print âˆ’1. Otherwise, print an integer k (0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ 3â‹…n) â€” the number of operations. Then print k integers p1,p2,â€¦,pk (1â‰¤pjâ‰¤nâˆ’1), where pj is the position of the left block in the pair of blocks that should be affected by the j-th operation. If there are multiple answers, print any of them. Examplesinput 8 BWWWWWWB output 3 6 2 4 input 4 BWBB output -1 input 5 WWWWW output 0 input 3 BWB output 2 2 1 NoteIn the first example, it is possible to make all blocks black in 3 operations. Start with changing blocks 6 and 7, so the sequence is â€œBWWWWBBBâ€œ. Then change blocks 2 and 3, so the sequence is â€œBBBWWBBâ€œ. And finally, change blocks 4 and 5, so all blocks are black. It is impossible to make all colors equal in the second example. All blocks are already white in the third example. In the fourth example it is possible to make all blocks white in two operations: first operation is to change blocks 2 and 3 (so the sequence is â€œBBWâ€œ), and then change blocks 1 and 2 (so all blocks are white). posts.text: #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; // T:ç¡®å®šå±äºæœ€å°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹é›†åˆ // S:å‰©ä½™èŠ‚ç‚¹é›†åˆ int a[3010][3010]; int d[3010];// d[x], xè¡¨ç¤ºxåŠ å…¥Tæ—¶é€‰å‡ºçš„æœ€å°è¾¹çš„æƒå€¼ bool vis[3010];// vis[x]==trueè¡¨ç¤ºè¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹å·²ç»åŠ å…¥äº†Té›†åˆ int n,m,ans=0; void prim() { memset(d,0x3f,sizeof(d)); memset(vis,0,sizeof(vis)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++)//å¾ªç¯n-1æ¬¡ æ¯æ¬¡æ‰¾å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹åŠ å…¥T { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++)//éå†æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹ { //å½“å‰d[]æ•°ç»„å­˜å‚¨çš„æ˜¯å„ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹è·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘çš„æœ€å°æƒå€¼ if(!vis[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) //!vis[j]è¡¨ç¤ºè¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹å°šæœªåŠ å…¥Té›†åˆ x=j; //é€‰å‡ºè·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘æœ€è¿‘çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ } vis[x]=1;//å°†è¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹åŠ å…¥åˆ°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ä¸­(Té›†åˆ) for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) { if(!vis[y])//æ–°åŠ äº†ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œå°±ç»´æŠ¤è¯¥ç‚¹åˆ°è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰åŠ å…¥Té›†åˆçš„ç‚¹çš„è·ç¦» d[y]=min(d[y],a[x][y]);//å–è·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ } } } int main() { cin>>n>>m; //æ„å»ºé‚»æ¥çŸ©é˜µ memset(a,0x3f,sizeof(a)); for(int i=1; i<=n; i++) a[i][i]=0; for(int i=1; i<=m; i++) { int x,y,z; cin>>x>>y>>z; a[x][y]=a[y][x]=min(a[x][y],z); } //æ±‚æœ€å°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ prim(); for(int i=2; i<=n; i++) ans+=d[i]; cout<<ans<<endl; return 0; } /* è¾“å…¥ è¾“å‡º15 6 10 1 2 6 1 3 1 1 4 5 2 3 5 2 5 3 3 4 5 3 5 6 3 6 4 4 6 2 5 6 6 */

posts.excerpt: æ™®é€šç‰ˆ int a[3010][3010],d[3010]; int n,m; bool v[3010]; void dijkstra() { memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); memset(v,0,sizeof(v)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++) { if(!v[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) x=j; } v[x]=1; for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) if(!v[y]) d[y]=min(d[y],d[x]+a[x][y]); } }
posts.text: æ™®é€šç‰ˆ int a[3010][3010],d[3010]; int n,m; bool v[3010]; void dijkstra() { memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); memset(v,0,sizeof(v)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++) { if(!v[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) x=j; } v[x]=1; for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) if(!v[y]) d[y]=min(d[y],d[x]+a[x][y]); } } å †ä¼˜åŒ–ç‰ˆ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; typedef long long ll; const int N = 1000010; const int INF = 0x3f3f3f3f; int n,m; struct edge { int to; int r; } ; typedef pair<int,int> P; vector<edge> a[N]; int d[50005]; void dijkstra(int s) { priority_queue<P,vector<P>,greater<P> >que; memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); d[s]=0; que.push(P(0,s)); while(que.size()) { P p=que.top(); que.pop(); int v=p.second; if(d[v]<p.first) continue; for(int i=0; i<a[v].size(); i++) { edge e=a[v][i]; if(d[e.to]>d[v]+e.r) { d[e.to]=d[v]+e.r; que.push(P(d[e.to],e.to)); } } } } int main() { cin>>n>>m; int x,y,r; while(m--) { cin>>x>>y>>r; edge t1,t2; t1.to=y; t1.r=r; t2.to=x; t2.r=r; a[x].push_back(t1); a[y].push_back(t2); } dijkstra(1); for(int i=0; i<=n; i++) cout<<d[i]<<" "; cout<<endl; return 0; }
